The rare moments when a characters life are in danger I used the rule above, but most often things just wrap up neatly. There’s someone that the team need to capture? Then they do it without any trouble. They need to sneak past some dogs and around a mansion? They get past easily. Anytime there is some kind of obstacle or resistance it resolves too quickly before the team start to struggle. This is a pitfall with having overpowered characters, but the show actually shows itself how to deal with this situation. It’s in my favourite part of episode 2, when the big bad is on the verge of discovering the spy’s identities. Ange and Dorothy are backed into a corner and have to think their way out fast. They pull off this on-the-fly plan thinking up the next step right as they finish the last, creating distractions to buy themselves time, swapping things without anyone noticing and all throughout this it feels like they’re a second away from being caught. They act as incredible spies while the scene also has lots of tension and I would have loved to have seen more of this. Also the threat of their identity being discovered was great and I think it could’ve been used in a few more places.


I also thought that the antagonist wasn’t used enough. Episode 2 introduces him as such a competent, cold bastard of a character and I was looking forward to seeing him clash against the team again. Despite this, from here until the finale he is only ever been mentioned in passing and feels as a vague threat. Gazelle, the spy who works for the antagonist only appears for a total of 2/3 times in acting out his will, though she never comes face to face with the team either. This is definitely a missed opportunity, I would have loved so much to see a showdown between for instance Gazelle and Dorothy. Then in the finale, when the antagonist finally starts to get into the spotlight and it looks like things are heating up he is side-lined by the most frustrating villain of all time. 


The villain drops in at episode 11 and succeeds in all of her plans while magically pushing aside any resistance. Ange for instance goes to great lengths to try and stop her and devises these clever plans, and in each case the only way the villain finds out is because the plot demands it, because there’s no reasonable way she would. She basically does what the team do to the majority of their missions and breezes through, though this is even worse because I at least enjoyed watching the team succeed. There are some shows that are just meant to make you feel good and in some episodes of Princess Principal it’s just that, there may be a lack of stakes but I’m still enjoying myself with the rich characters and setting, the music and action scenes that are just plain fun. The same cannot be said when this villain is present because I’m just frustrated by how untouchable she is which she doesn’t earn it at all.


When the team finally defeated her it didn’t feel like they’d faced off but more that her powers of being unstoppable had just been turned down, she was suddenly made an even match. It lead to a very “That’s it?” feeling. What made it worse was that the plot that was going on between Ange and Princess was really interesting and I thought it carried the finale, with moments from each team member chipping in at just the right time. The best way to summarise the finale is that it felt like drinking spoilt milk, because I knew it had the potential to be really good and the villain was the biggest cause of spoiling it.


On the whole I really enjoyed Princess Principal and I think it’s something that’s likely to have flown under most people’s radar because of the flawed first episode. I think the finale is just plain average and somewhat feels like it belongs in a different show, which makes it feel like a let-down in comparison to the greatness that’s around it. I would still 100% recommend it though, as a fan of episodic shows this really scratched an itch for me, I had lots of fun watching it and its exact blend is so unique I’m not sure I’ll see something like it again. I’d say lots of creativity, care and love was put into this, because that’s what shows when you watch one of the episodes. We need a season 2. 8.5/10

An amazingly styled animation, steampunk era anime.
It also brings a nice amount of action and unrealistic but fun to watch spy business.
The story is progressing in a good pace, has depth, and makes you cry when it wants to.
Storyline has a great amount of twists and unexpected turns.
Characters are deep and you can cling on them very hard a lot of the times. Each of them have(or will have) an explanation and backstory as to how they came to this point, further enhancing the depth of them.
This is the subbed version im reviewing, I dont know if there is a dubbed one, but watching bothversions might be more beneficial than just one of them.\n\n
Cannot wait for the next season.\n\n
A must watch, especially if you like steampunk and story-heavy anime with a moderate scoop of action

There's a bunch of stuff that floated up in the back of my mind when watching, regarding the suspension of disbelief - like how the characters were pulling off all these actions that you'd think would draw more attention, and how the Princess seemed to be able to maneuver so freely without any suspicion being raised - but the first episode has a top-hat Arsene Lupin-esque moegirl using a magical gravity ball to fly around, and she's accompanied by a loli-samurai, so who gives a shit about suspension of disbelief?
Princess Principal is pretty fun, and the episodes are short and full of basic tropes (thebasic story is Prince and the Pauper + a variety of spy cliches like double-agents and backstabs) cobbled together into something fast-paced, action-packed, and cutesy. The story is well-structured enough such that you aren't lost even if its out of chronological order, which serves no purpose to anything deeper, but is a great display of Ichiro Okouchi's ability to do entertainment pacing. I felt like the episode that stretched things a bit too far from me (and I'm a person who feels like I can suspend my disbelief very easily) is episode seven - but that episode makes up for it by having a chock full of moegirls.


The ending peters out a bit too. It feels to clean, since there's a great change that occurs extremely vast, and is resolved just as fast. Really, it's there to incite quick emotions and give a sense of triumph to the ending. 


Animation is stellar. Setting looks cool as hell. Sound is Yuki Kajiura.


If you want crazier spy stuff, just watch the 1967 TV series called The Prisoner - which is actually great, as well as entertaining.

I found a good anime. They said it was amazing so I decided to take a look and yet I stumbled another overrated anime. Some of you might disagree with me but it is TRULY OVERRATED. I don't get the high rating, maybe it's their taste?? I don't know. Let's begin the review:
To start it off, the first scenes were badass, truly enjoyable and action packed anime. It was indeed worth watching at first then here comes the background story of each characters which is worth to know. Everything went fine then everything went downhill. It is later some episodes became confusing in the middle.No sense of the timeline whether if it is the past or present. The story is repetitive, still not bad. It became a drama anime instead of action which is a big minus for me. And the last scenes were amazing again.


The characters are OK. Good character development. The animation is amazing.  The enjoyment like I said earlier it went downhill and repetitive. Although I recommend this anime to everyone. I suggest lower your expectations and you might enjoy it.


Overall:6/10

Story (8/10):
With the premise of the show you would expect your usual action anime with cute girls and fan service but you would be greatly mistaken
Nothing about this show is at it seems It happens rarely that an anime will have so many plot twist an not be confusing as fuck but this show did that masterfully, giving you all the information but keeping you guessing at the same time.
Some of the ideas and interaction presented in the show were "Real As Fuck" as in real life stuff and nothing of that starry dreams bullshit. It still gives you the usual hopeful future stuff butit had a good balance with the real stuff.

The show offered solid action, a decent amount of comedy and some feels giving you a nicely packaged anime


Characters (8/10):

The characters were well established. Every single character was presented in a nice way and had their background explained giving them depth and a reason behind their actions and motivations.

All the main characters were lovable and down to earth, nothing really outrageous or funky just simple girls affected by their pasts and experiences and acting upon their beliefs 


Art and Animation (8/10):

The characters looked beautiful and cute and the environments were well made it was a good representation of industrial London with how the coloring and art were maded

The animations were extremely good. movements were well executed which made the action scenes look more intense and fun

it was really visually appealing


Music & VA (8/10):

Gotta love that jazz soundtrack it really helped with setting the mood of the show and made it more enjoyable. The OP was fantastic and the ED was not half bad

The Voice acting was good as well the voices suited the character and there was no annoying sounding characters


Effectiveness (8/10):

This is definitely a new show to be added to my favorite list. i actually watched the whole thing in one sitting because i enjoyed it so much. The ending was kind of predictable and I am a little sad that they didn't finish up the story but i am also a little happy that i will get to watch more if it gets a new season (hopefully it gets one and it get executed right and not disappoint)


Overall (8/10)

Steampunk is one of my all time favourite styles and settings for a story beaten out only by perhaps Tolkienesque fantasy so when I saw that we'd get an anime with a steampunk aesthetic that was aiming to combine spy action with cute girls I instantly jumped on board. And, I thought, since it's an anime original then at least we will get a conclusive ending.
Princess Principal seemed almost too well suited to my taste to be true. So now, after twelve episodes and a few months what did I think of it?
In short, it was pretty good. However, you may want to hear morethan just that if you're reading a review so here we go:


As mentioned above the setting of Princess Principal is a heavily stylised and steampunk Victorian Era London. Now this is not your regular version of London either, it's a city caught inbetween two warring nations with a big wall in the middle to serve as a divider. Think something along the lines of the real life Berlin wall.

In this city we follow a rather colourful cast of characters that sticks out like a sore thumb among most of the other inhabitants of the city, nevermind the fact that they're supposed to be spies. The show mostly carries itself on these two points: the characters and the setting. There is an overarching plot, but the show is told in a very episodic manner with each episode being a particular case that the girls tackle and the semi-random case numbers we get for these give a pretty good indication that there's really not supposed to be much of a connection between these.

Some reoccuring characters and the above mentioned overarching plot do pop up in almost every episode, but they're never the main focus and as I'll talk about later they don't quite serve a purpose either.


Moving on to the characters, I feel that as an ensemble of varied personalities, skills and backgrounds they work quite well. The show tries to dedicate entire episodes to the characters fleshing them out as best it can while also giving you an interesting episode to watch and moving the plot forward by a little. If you don't like flashbacks you might not have a lot of fun with a couple of the episodes in the show which are almost entirely flashbacks.

The main cast consists of the „alien” Ange, the prim and proper Princess, the no-nonsense ninja Chise, bubbly Beatrice and the voluptuous vixen Dorothy. Your enjoyment of the show is largerly going to depend on whether or not you like any of these characters. And I did like them. Now, like a lot of other moe shows the characters are somewhat shallow, even after getting flashbacks and emotional sequences with some of them I couldn't really relate to them or see them as full human beings. They're abstractions of human beings not meant to have deep personalities or relatable personas. And because of this they're just slightly above average. I'll probably forget about them soon enough.

However, I do have to praise the character designs for being extremely good. From the clothing to the faces and hair everything fits with the characters' personalities and looks really good. I especially love Ange in her cloak and top hat.


Now as mentioned above the show is light on plot, opting to go for a more episodic approach where each episode, aside from maybe the final two are standalone stories which could be viewed out of order just fine. I do not have problem with this setup. I think it gives the show a chance to showcase each of the main girls in an environment which suits them without being constrained by having to follow a linear plot. There's something for everyone in the show's eclectic mix of situations, from helping a laundromat stay afloat in an episode that plays out mostly like any other slice of life show to trainhopping trying to stop Japanese assassins at two hundred kilometers per hour.

The overarching plot that does get showcased deals with the Princess and Ange's backstory and future in trying to unite the country. Only the last couple of episodes really deal with this head on while the rest mostly shove it to the side. It's basically like playing an RPG and ignoring the main questline until the very end just so you can do all the sidequests. That's really what the show feels like. With maybe the exception that you get tired of doing the main quest partway through and just stop. I want to talk about the ending a bit here, and don't worry I won't spoil anything major. The ending seems to setup for a second season, but since the show barely finished airing and there is no second season announcement in sight I can only go off of what we have which is a rather incomplete anime. This is a shame since I genuinely thought that with it being an anime original we would get a conclusive and final ending. Now if a second season does ever come this point is moot, but until then it will bug me.


From a visual standpoint the show looks quite impressive at times. The steampunk setting certainly helps, with designs and locations that are really well done and fit the theme like wind-up smoke grenades, huge steam-powered airships and early twentieth century cars. I already praised the character designs for the show above and they're just about as good for most of the side-characters as well, at least the women. The men in the show all share the same basic look and frankly just look bland compared to their female counterparts.

The animation is looks good for the most part, even in the action scenes where they use some CG it still looks good. However I have an issue with how clean and sterile everything feels, we're supposed to be in a grimy and impoverished London yet almost every major character is squeaky clean and positively glowing. This is where I feel like the art style and setting clash. On the one hand you can't have a show about cute girls without also having a vibrant and clean artsyle, on the other you also want that vibrant and clean artstyle to portrai a dark and serious world. The show tries to have its cake and eat it too, but it doesn't quite make it. Something simply feels off in the way the show is presented.


Overall I felt like Princess Principal was a fun romp through a steampunk world teeming with evildoers and cute spies. It's not the best show of Summer 2017 but it is up there and I definitely recommend it to anyone who is curious about it. It's worth watching not only for its rather unique setting, but also for the characters and action present here. Just be ready to be left in the dark by the ending. Unless you're reading this way into the future and a season two has already come out that is.

Cute girls show that actually takes itself seriously? Well....anything works I guess? Who would have thought this show would work so well? This is easily one of the most surprising anime of the year! This show was a joint project between studios Studio 3Hz and Actas. This series is directed by Masaki Tachibana who is best known as the director of Barakamon. He has also worked on shows such as Flip Flappers and Ghost in the Shell Stand Alone Complex and 2nd Gig. This is his second director gig. The writing for the series is handled by Ichirō Ōkouchi who is best known for hiswork on the Code Geass series. 


Princess Principal is one of the few CGDT shows to get something right that many of the shows of this genre don't do.  What is that? Well to put it simply, it's the characters and writing. 


Before I jump into the meat of this review, I just wanted to explain my main complaint with CGDT (Cute Girls Doing Things) shows. My main problem with shows like these is how the characters lack depth, and their no clear end goal. It just feels like 12 or 24 episodes of them checking off a list of anime tropes and clichés. There is no attempt to make the characters stand out besides being a whatever anime archetype they are. 


Thankfully, Princess Principal is one of the few shows to get this right. A show like Princess Principal doesn't need to be just cute for their concept to work. What it does do is show you, that giving a character an episode to flush them out can pay off in the long run. We start to like the character for who she is and not because she is cute. Cute can be an aspect of liking a character, but when it is pretty much their whole character. There is nothing. 


Now, let's get onto the review. I know that is what you have been waiting for. I'm happy to give you what you want. We are going to Black Lizard Planet. 


Story (8 out of 10): Our story takes place in the fictional world of Albion, England. During the 20th century of the Kingdom of Albion has control and monopolized this mysterious substance. This has led to unrest among the citizens of Albion. So, a couple of years later, the Commonwealth launches an operation known as Changeling in an attempt to replace the current ruling class in power with Ange. A girl that have chosen due to how she looks like the princess. The princess catches wind of their plan and offers to help them with their plans if the Commonwealth promises her that she can become Queen of the Kingdom. 


The story of PP (Princess Principal) isn't an overarching plot but more so episodic plots that end up connecting later. They make sure each character gets their moments in the spotlight to shrine. Mr. Ōkouchi really makes sure every character is flushed out to the best of his abilities. But he doesn't do the same for the villains of the show as they are barely around. He does a good job framing them as a threat, but they rarely cross paths with our main heroines making them seem like wasted potential. 


Besides that, it also can be unfocused sometimes with focusing on things that are not important to the plot. For example, in episode 7, it feels like more of a side mission in an open world game than am an actual meaningful episode to advance the plot and characters. The same can be said for some missions they go on. I am always asking myself, "What does this have to do with the plot?" Like there is one mission at the end of the series that felt out of place to me. 


Overall, the story is good but lacks a good villain to oppose our girls. So, you're left with cute, interesting girls beating up grown men. I really like the beginning of the series as it serves as a good introduction to our cast. I also like the direction they went with the ending leaving it open for a season two since a season two was only as they were really going to fully realize their vision for what they want to do. 


Art (9 out of 10): As stated before Studio 3Hz and Actas were done the animation for this project. And they both really come out swinging. Actas doesn't always have the best animation, but they really surprised me here with this show. I can tell Studio 3Hz handle majority of the action scenes as each one is unique and different. I think Actas handled the big booming perspective shots. All of them are exciting and intense. So, they knew what they were doing in that department. 


The character designs were done by Kouhaku Kuroboshi. Who I know from his illustration work from Kino's Journey. First off, I would like to tip my cap to Mr. Kuroboshi for his unique designs for all the female characters. He really makes every girl in the show look different. You can tell who is the oldest and youngest among our five main girls. He really gives them expressions through their clothes, that can really tell who they are as a character. He also makes sure their eyes are designed. When you look at the girls you can tell how each of them looks different. Ange’s eyes have a sharper and darker look while Beatrice’s eyes are a lighter color. 


Though, I feel this is lacking when it comes to the male character designs. Every guy in the show looks bland and boring. No one really stands out even the boss of the girl has a mediocre design. The same goes for our villain. I can say overall, he really nails the 20th century Victorian London style. I think my favorite designs of the show are Ange, Dorothy, and Gazelle. So, overall, I think the artwork and animation are really good. 


Character (10 out of 10): Now onto my favorite part of this show. this show is really driven by its amazing characters. The characters of this show are nothing less than fantastic. I am talking about the main characters of course. Let's down the line and talk about how effective each of them is. 


Ange: The queen of Black Lizard Planet. Ange is just a lot of fun. One of her main concepts and calling cards is her ability to lie and tell when someone is lying. She also has the ability to change her personality depending on the situation. You can never tell when she is being honest unless it involves one of the other major characters in the show. She is very laid back and is very aware of her surrounds. Ange never tells you who she is unless she uses the cover of "Black Lizard Planet" to tell someone about herself.  Yes, she can use the anti-gravity machine she carries, but I feel her power to outsmart everyone around her is even better. She is the all-around member of the group if you ask me. 


Beatrice: She joins the team later. She is the younger member of the group but has a very dark backstory that involves her father using her as an experiment. So, she now has a voice box. With this voice box, she is able to change her voice to match any voices she hears. This is very helpful when they’re on missions. It's a really unique ability. She isn't the best fighter of the team, but combat isn't her focus. She plays more of the role of gathering intel. I love her expression and how she really keeps herself calm when on these missions since she is the most likely to die. Great character, and really has her heart in the right place. She only joins because the person serves joins. So, she is very loyal. 


Chise: Up next is the only Japanese member of the group. Oh, I forgot to mention everyone is British in this show. Anyway, Chise is the samurai of the group. She is the main the hand to hand fighter of the group.  So, she takes care of any bad guys that get close. Her character reminds of a rule 63 loli Goemon. That doesn't mean she is bad. Her backstory in her first episode it was okay. The other episode she got was really cool. I do wish they went more into the reckless side of her. Overall, she is just a solid character being the typical samurai. Her costume is really cool. 


Dorothy: Now time to talk about my favorite character of the show! Dorothy is the femme fatale of the group while also being the leader. She is the most level-headed of the girls and is cool under pressure.  Dorothy never really does enough to much of a whore. She knows how to use her body right. She really plays the role of the femme fatale. Dorothy is very sexy and a very strong female character. She always knows what to do. Her backstory is not a bad angle with her being abused by her father. Her real name is Daisy. She changed it to Dorothy. In her episode, you really got to see how she became the strong and powerful woman she is today. It's very well done. 


Princess: The last member of this group and one of the most interesting. She is the public figure of the group. Princess is also the only reason Beatrice joined the team. She is the only one that can freely move around without having to hide her image. Princess is the most inexperienced in being a spy (same goes for Beatrice) but she proves to be very clever. She isn't one for combat, so just like Beatrice and a little bit of Ange. Her best ability is to be able to outsmart her foes. Now there is a huge plot twist involving her and Ange that I won't spoil, but I will say it was amazing and really will make you like Princess and Ange even more.


Lastly, I want to talk about Gazelle. I really wanted to see more of her because I felt she could have been a good foe for the girls. When she is on the screen she is really making her presence known. She is evil and very brutal. Episode six is one of the best examples of her being outright brutal to someone. She along with the other guy really needed more screen time. I hope they get more in a second season.  I do think she has a great design though. 


Sound (9 out of 10: The opening theme is solid getting that spy theme perfect, but I feel the ED really nails the moe factor with a cute upbeat song with some really good animation. I also felt the voice acting all over was solid. I felt the voice actors really did a good job of being the characters than just being an archetype. I think the strongest performances of the show were Ange and Dorothy if you ask me. Lastly, I felt the sound effects for the guns and explosions were nice and didn't feel stock. So, I feel the show has some good sound design. 


Overall (9 out of 10): Princess Principal is easily one of the most underrated shows of the year. This show was such a treat to watch. I really like how they made the character the center focus, and we could take what they're doing seriously. This wasn't cute girls playing kickball. These young girls working deep undercover as spies and acting like spies. I highly recommend shows for anyone who is a huge Lupin the Third fan and those that have wanted more depth when it comes to moe shows.

“Those who know how to tell a good lie are the ones who survive in this world” 
An original production from studio 3 HZ and Actas , Princess Principal features  5 girls as the main cast into the world of spies full of lies. With badass and beautiful girls , with a catchy opening song that fits the overall jazzy atmosphere and a lot of action in the spy world Princess Principal does  everything how is supposed to be done:RIGHT!  . “Let’s begin our mission!”.
I mentioned that this anime does everything right , why? Well we have everything that is supposed tosee in an action packed  anime about spies: car chasing, infiltrations , disguise, assassination missions , plot twists that happen during a mission and many more , all is done with the 5 main girls who take advantage of their  special abilities to survive and get results  into this world of spies . The pace in this anime is exactly what defines the life of a spy: During the day you blend amongst  the commoners and carry out your relaxing and mundane lifestyle and during the night you put on your “coat” and “gloves” and carry out the missions you’re entrusted with . A life with accomplishments  which will never come to the day light a whole life living in the  shadows  losing your humanity and individuality by each day.


The unorthodox  storytelling  makes Princess Principal more captivating and exciting for its audience.The first episode presents the overall image of what this anime offers , it introduces its audience to the 20th century England atmosphere , to our 5 main girls and  doesn’t waste any time cutting corners and dives directly into the  world of spies full of action and lies. The main story is like a jigsaw puzzle which is filled by  the mystery revealed in each episode giving born to the whole image of the puzzle known as Princess Principal. Set in a 20th century  fictional analogue of England called Albion the story manages to maintain its nostalgic atmosphere of those times throughout all 12 episodes  . A big contribute to that are the classical architecture of the buildings ,  the steam train and finally the lifestyle of the people from  those times.


The 5 main girls blend perfectly into the spy world  making it more easy for the viewer to get  accustomed  to the anime main plot and story. Since the story is episodic each girl has her own spotlight to shine and conquer the heart of the audience. That’s the main purpose of a character into a story to be fleshed out and get a emotional or moral attachment from the viewers. The personalities and unique quirks of each girl is what makes them stand out  and with a little drama added to their background stories their characters became a firm foundation for the story. I like how natural they act in each situation according to their own age and experience. We have Chise who acts exactly as an Asian when visiting a foreign country , misunderstanding a lot of the local habits but the same can be said about those around her who aren’t familiar with her country traditions and habits. Beatrice the  youngest  among the 5 girls , despite being a crybaby  she offers a lot of support in each mission despite being just a beginner as a spy. Dorothy  the oldest from the 5 girls and their leader , let’s say that she is the most essential member for the team to work as a whole. She knows how to use her best weapon(femininity) to make any mission a success. Ange who always carry out a mission and dirty her hands for the success of it  and finally the Princess who pulls a lot of strings from the shadows .


But in Princess Principal is not all about badass girls kicking the ass of the bad guys in each mission, the anime also focuses on the current lifestyle of the people from the 20th century Albion.  Their stories carry a lot of emotion and  the hardships they must overcome to survive during those times steal a tear from its audience.  The mysterious and beautiful bond between Ange&Charlotte which the story focuses on  is brilliant handled across the 12 episodes  revealing a piece of the puzzle in each episode  as the story  progresses. When the final piece is revealed and the mystery  solved the overflowing  emotions  are visible in the form of tears streaming down your cheeks. 


The opening song and the animation  is brilliant done having a connection to the whole plot , atmosphere and characters from the anime. It portrays exactly the personalities of the  5 main girls , Beatrice a crybaby, Ange a badass , Dorothy fearless of each situation, Chise taking upon each challenge that comes in her sight and finally the Princess who is saved by Ange implying the bond and past .


Princess Principal is an enjoyable anime overall with a lot of fights who give you a bump of adrenaline ,  with beautiful and badass girls who are damn capable and know how to conquer your attention  and finally with a well handled transition between the jazzy tense atmosphere and the  emotional one. Don’t be fooled by the unorthodox order of the episodes they are released with a purpose  so it’s worth your time this anime.

“Mission Accomplished”

As at the start of every review I do. I will say that I look at and review a show/film from a professional/critical point of view. This means taking into account even the smallest details of every scene through the show's running time which ultimately lead up to my conclusion of the shows overall score. Due to this fact, I will not be using my opinions as argument points, nor will they have an effect on the score.
If I were to write something personal (it would be written like this inside of some brackets)
Now, let's get started shall we?
[Misunderstandings] - The show's title really makesthe viewer think its about a different thing, most people I've talked to about this think the same thing. The title is a bit misleading, and that is nor a good or bad thing. Many people (including myself) thought that this was going to be another school, slice of life anime set in a victorian esk steampunk world. In fact it is about something completely different. I'll leave the synopsis to do my job for me there.

With this out of the way, we can get into the meat of the review.


[Story] 6/10 - Having, to re-watch episodes to understand the plot is a bad thing. I've had to rewatch several episodes. Though not the whole series. To find and identify the plot. A way of putting how the show makes it's plot is a per episode system. Kinda like how every episode is like a different "Adventure" for the characters. The creators also thought that spreading the story's plot over several "Case files" is a bit weak and shows that they couldn't connect the plot over the whole series. There are around 4 episodes, that connect chronologically but the rest of the anime's "case files" are scattered around chronologically. Forcing the viewer to make connections from a previous episode that took place some time before the episode you were watching. To make this more clear im going to use an example, this has nothing to do with spoilers to don't worry. (If i accidentally connect the episodes without knowing I will fix it). You are watching episode 7 and the "case file" number is 24. Though in episode 6 the "case file" number was 35. Meaning you have to eventually either connect them all chronologically without having all of the case numbers. Which is bad plot design, it would've been better if they designed the show chronologically somehow. But that is a minor fix to the problem. The plot is very convoluted, it makes you think which is a good thing if done right, and it keeps the show fresh. Making different settings and episode feel better or worse than the previous one.


[Art/Animation] 10/10 - Fresh and creative design choices are a key factor into making something great. This is probably the best part about the show overall. It's Art style is breath taking and amazingly animated. Making every action scene fun and amazingly creative. You could tell the creators had fun making each scene, as it looks as if they poured their hearts and souls into it. It's fluid and rarely bad. (There is one or two scenes that are a bit spotty but it took me a while to notice them and when I did it wasn't that bad of a mistake either). Now the design of the world could have been a bit less gloomy, but that's what makes a mood for a show. It fleshes out it's world and setting almost instantly too. Showing off exactly what the animators and designers are capable of.


[Sound] 9/10 - Sound/Music choice can make or break a scene. (I say this in almost every review in this section). Staring off with music choice, let's hit two birds with one stone shall we? The OP and ED are amazing, a fully english OP really caught me off guard. But some other anime do the same thing and it's just plain bad. This anime's OP is Amazing. It's creatively a masterpiece. The ED takes on a different style from the rest of the show but it doesn't seem out of place. Now... scenes either do or don't have music in them. It's a choice that the creators have full control over. But many creators need to know that no music at all can make a scene much much better, increasing the mood a ton. An example would be if two characters were arguing and loud almost battle like music was playing it would take away from the scene. But if you didn't have any music and focused on the characters voices and the sound of their movements. It can make an argument scene super intense. In this anime there are a bunch of scenes with out of place music. Which is why this isn't a perfect 10. Sound, this is basically the sound of all of the movements, footsteps, weapon noises, metal, objects, etc. (I think you get it.) Is pretty well done, the sounds of everything don't take away from any of the scenes. Which is a good thing. If you show has horrible sound design it can make scenes horrible. Just by the minor sounds.


[Character] 7/10 - The character design is amazing and creative. That's all that there is too it. Nothing negative to say about the design. But there is one problem. Character Development. In this department it lacks a bit. It seemed as if the show used it's plot as an excuse to to not develop characters. Near the later-half of the show it starts to develop characters and maybe one or two episodes are set aside for minor development of character, but it should've found a way to develop the characters throughout the whole series. Start to finish.


[Enjoyment] 10/10 - This is a personal section of the review so I will not be using brackets here. I had an absolute BLAST watching this show, it was so flipping awesome I cannot describe how cool some of the action scenes are. When I wasn't distracted by trying to piece together the plot I was watching it with a huge grin on my face, almost every episode made me smile and get a little giddy from how awesome it is. This is a perfect show to watch with friends as I guarantee you will have a good time. 


[Overall Score] 8/10 - Even with the shotty plot and horribly fleshed out characters, this is a great anime. Both in the technical and the enjoyment factor. This show wasn't afraid to jump directly into the action with was one of it's strong points. Throughout the whole shows running time, it had decently good episode. Like above, some episodes were really good while some were bad. Not really bad. But just bad. Do I recommend this anime? YES Absolutely yes! If you want to get into the action genre this is a great place to start. While other anime's are better for getting it, this is definitely one you should check out. Give it the good ole 3 episode chance. If I was able to review the show in its whole (which means using spoilers and per episode reviews) I would be able to further express how amazing this show is.


Thanks for tuning in! Hope you found this review helpful

Princess Principal is a beautiful hidden gem, the more you look at it, the more mesmerizing and elegant it becomes.
There's just something subtle about this show that entices you to keep watching.
Whether it may be the 1890s vibe, James Bond spy feel or how every episode is a rollercoaster, Princess Principal is, similar to the cute girl spies, a clandestine masterpiece.
To start off, many complain about the atrocious and unsatisfying ending. That it doesn't "work" for them. Maybe Princess should have perished in the last scene or how Sentai played it too safe. 
However, I beg to differ.
I believe the ending was expertly paved fora season 2. 


If one really take the time to logically think, it's a brilliant set-up as it allowed for a new set of antagonists (Zelda and Gazelle), a clear goal (getting Princess to be queen) and ultimately, the fulfillment of Operation: Changeling (what this anime was about).


Let's not forget to mention how the anime took the effort to masterfully give us a Suzumiya Haruhi feel with each episode set in the past or future. Extra shoutout for the rhythm and alliteration.


Ep 1- Case 13 Wired Liar

Ep 2 - Case 1 Dancy Conspiracy

Ep 3 - Case 2 Vice Voice

Ep 4 - Case 9 Roaming Pigeons

Ep 5 - Case 7 Bullet and Blade's Ballad

Ep 6 - Case 18 Rouge Morgue

Ep 7 - Case 16 Loudly Laundry

Ep 8 - Case 20 Ripper Dipper

Ep 9 - Case 11 Pell-mell Duel

Ep 10 - Case 22 Comfort Comrade

Ep 11 - Case 23 Humble Double

Ep 12 - Case 24 Fall of the Wall



※ STRENGTH ※


► Strong individual characters. If you think of Ange, what words come to mind? How about Charlotte? Or Princess? That is the power of individuality. Where the characters have their own sets of personality that solely define who they are as a human being in which they stand out from others. That is strong character creation done well.


► Enemy of my enemy is my friend. The art of deception and deceit. Getting the result even when the tactics may be dirty. Espionage and reconnaissance with a hint of betrayal at any given moment. The vibe of unpredictability. Acting differently to get the optimal results. What more can you ask for from a spy anime?


► There is something to take away in every episode. This just really shows you how carefully crafted each story and character development is in each segment. Which ultimately led up to the big plot twist and the continuation of Operation: Changeling paired with some slight emotional rollercoasters along the railway.


► That plot twist. Yes. You know which one. I, and many others, didn't see it coming but that development just boosts the anime up to another tier.


► Relatable. There is bound to be one person you are rooting for in the spy team. You do that because you feel for them. Somehow you empathize and relate. That is an epitome of an anime done well.


► Each character has their own story. There is no leaving a story untold. It offers an answer to your questions throughout the journey. And you fill in the blanks yourself afterwards.


► Music. Art. Transitions. Sceneries. Take the time and go back. See how every tiny detail adds up to give that 1900s feel. A lot of anime can do it but not a lot can do it right.



※ WEAKNESS ※ 


► Yuri. Girl on girl. Although this is not specifically portrayed but the indication is there. This may be uncomfortable and turn off some viewers. I personally don't mind as a ship has already sailed.



Would I recommend? Hell YES!!!!!!


Would I rewatch? No doubt at it, already planning it with a friend.


All in all, this show caught me off guard first episode in as the spies quickly took me down then carried me along in their missions. Through those objectives, I laughed and felt the emotional impact they left as the show came to an end.


There's nothing more that needs to be mentioned besides the announcement of season 2.

"Princess Principal" 
What do you think when you hear those words for the first time? I made an assumption it was another typical school anime and skipped it for over a month but then one day I happened to come across it when I had nothing to watch so I checked it out. I couldn't have been any more wrong, and what was in store for me over the course of 12 episodes was beyond me at the time.
♚Story: 10/10
-Princess Principal is unique, creative, and really draws you in the more you watch. It starts out action-packed, and goes through many different levels in termsof spy missions and interactions. The story itself is about a secret spy war between the Kingdom and Commonwealth of Albion.


-The main characters are a group of spies who pose as regular students by day, dangerous spies with particular diverse skills by night. The story never really dips in quality, so it really keeps you wanting more the entire time. Overall, out of my current 1,600+ anime episodes watched I haven't found another story like this one and it's brilliant.


♚Artwork: 9/10

-The art in this anime is made of a "steampunk" theme, and it definitely shows through the technology, factories, and overall colors of the background and everything. It's clean, very fitting for the anime, and the animation is great during fight scenes and all as well.


♫Sound: 9/10 

-The OP is amazing, and sets up the stage for each and every episode quite nicely. It's one of those openings that goes especially well with the climatic final episodes! The ED is alright, I find it funny that it gives off that hopeless, tired feeling that Konosuba's season 2 ending gives off~ 


-The overall soundtracks played through the anime are also decent, and all do their job as needed. Nothing super extraordinary like Haikyuu, but still pretty decent.


♚Character: 9/10

-The characters of this anime are what really make this show memorable. On top of the already unique story and uncommon artwork/soundtracks, each character has a "spy side". It's like how everyone has that part of themselves they don't want to show to others, but in this anime that side takes over and actually creates a sort of inner conflict from within. The actual complexity and beauty of the characters and what makes them so amazing can't be described with words, however that being said this is a little preview:


-Dorothy is essentially the big sister of the group, and she tries to keep it real as much as possible. She's also at the root of a lot of the group's humor, and definitely keeps them all together as a sort of "leader."


-Ange is a double agent to herself, and this takes on multiple meanings throughout the show. She almost always lies, and it's clear if she were to give in to the truth she would lose herself in the emotions. Lies are a way of her keeping herself together, and in different situations of her lying you can really understand what she's feeling and the emotions that run from within her. She is definitely the yin to Dorothy's yang.


-Chise is the foreigner of the group, it's funny how in a Japanese anime, she is displayed as a Japanese foreigner and actually seems more "Japanese" than most characters in pretty much any other anime. Like Dorothy, much of the humor and also the sense of unknowing and diversity stems from her character. At first she seems like the new girl that comes in and quickly fits in, but then you see that just like all the others, she too has that second drastically different emotional side.


-Princess is what lies over the "wall" blocking Ange's heart. She represents everything bright, but also a distant melancholy almost as if she's calling out to someone.. She helps to further prove that the spies do more than just follow orders, they follow the orders with EMOTION. This builds up meaning throughout the anime.


-Beatrice is "the voice" of the show. She ties into all the other characters and pulls them together. She displays the most emotion and is seemingly least cut out for the job, but like the others in the group her place there is so much more than what she looks like to start out with.


♚Enjoyment: 10/10

-In conclusion, each and every episode fills you with different warm and powerful feelings and is very entertaining. I thoroughly enjoyed how the characters developed, the soundtracks, the way the story is structured, the artwork, and how the sound created something that I think new anime coming out need. Something unique, giving off a new feeling and really showing what you can do especially in only 12 episodes!


♛Overall: 9/10

-In the end, actual appreciation for this beautiful work of art comes down to the person. The way everything in this show is set up makes it brilliant and unique, and for that I can confidently say that the producers and everyone who helped to create it did an amazing job. To anyone that reads this review and decides to then watch the anime, I hope you find every bit as much enjoyment as I did in it!~

This show was good fun in an original involving two companies. Unfortunately he had a series of holes in the story ending in the open. Something I believe to have a motive behind. Unfortunately I can not explain exactly what that goal would be, as it would hurt the site's guidelines, as has already occurred previously in another comment of mine. Interesting story, music note 10, and ambience very well done. Somehow captivating characters. Highly recommend to anyone who wants something different, but be warned beforehand that there are holes in the history, which may perhaps disappoint some.
That is all

For starters I believe this anime is strongly underrated and that it deserves a worth audience that will praise it. If you are a fan of steampunk, a Sherlock Holmes, detective, spy-like kind of show, you'll enjoy this anime trust me.
Story: The Kingdom of Albion is brought back into another original anime. This isn't the first anime I've seen mentioning this domain. It's the 19th century and what makes the case for this story known is the wall that divides the East and West of the capital of Albion. Five high school girls, who enroll in the prestigious Queens May Fair School are involved inheavily activities that is considered spy work. Disguise, infiltration, car chase, and more. What happens next is how the girls use that advantage in this kind of world to fly high. 


To me, this story plot left me confused the first 6 EP's. To put it blunt, I didn't think strongly of the anime at first. The unchronological story telling. It would focus one week on the story and the next EP would tell how it came to be. Now this indeed would make most think that's how it's post to be. But aren't you post to tell a story in order instead of all over the place? I was unsure of myself if I'd even get through this. I am even stated soon on Twitter. Once I got by EP 6 though I accepted what the studio was trying to do. This original may require patience for some. Others will be snatched on the very first EP. I got the feeling when reading comments about the series from my pals on twitter which led me to speak up, "Why". Anyway, the story is quite entertaining with the dividing of two sides. The Commonwealth and of course, the kingdom itself. I was never a big fan of Spying or being stealthy because it's my weakest link when playing video games that way or trying to steal something when hungry. *sighs*. You have to admire the way the anime plays this all out and how it treats the characters. As rough it may be, so is life. Ouch. I give the story a 7/10.



Next up is Art: An 8/10 for me. Just like mecha. I'm a big fan of steam punk or unique setting like the 18th or 19th century like this anime has. I was amazed. It felt realistic. Watching the anime kind of reminded me heavily of Sherlock Holmes/London type setting. That's how heavy the art impacted me. The design for the characters was real classy. The way it should. Watch for yourself, you may get a different feel than I did. 


Sound: I want dive into this section much. lol. I was too focus on enjoying than listening in on sound. I'll give it an 8 for well timed sound organization. Not to mention for making my ears ring at times. 



Character/Characters: An 8 here but let me tell why. 



Ange: The most cold hearted character out of the 5 girls. At least at first. She acts strongly on being a spy. Liars have their part it feels like coming from her. She's emotionless. Her face will not show it due to her past. She's good at what she does. Could she be a better example? Yes, I believe she can if the show ever receives more. Doubt it. 


Princess: Obviously it shows that she and Ange have a past together. A cruel one. Panned out to turn this plot/story into a real ride down memory lane. Painful or not. The princess over the 10 year period really learns to love the country she's in. Wants to rid the walls that divide the land of Albion. I admire a leader like that. Young even. However, problems can't be solved easily. She'll learn this over the course of the 12 EP's. Watch this series and you'll find out what I mean. 



Chise: Don't we always love our Japanese girls? Ha, ha. Well, Chise I really felt was a strange girl. Obviously has a past like the other 4 girls in the group and doesn't wish to talk about it unless it's the right moment. Most do. Her lord from the land of East Japan commands her to go to Queens May to learn about the operation/and decide what to do going further. Chise has skills that she learned from her dad and I respect her for doing what she does in this series. Just being there despite the outsider tag slapped on her. I will go into this no more. Try to watch this anime for yourself. I feel they could've done more with her if the series was longer than 12 EP's. 


Dorothy: I believe she was the oldest. Anyway, she acts more like an older sister 3/4 of the time. Very mature. I could easy respect her if I was listening in on taking advise. However, like the other girls her past plays a part too. It certainly does hold her back for a time until she learns to overcome it. I think Dorothy ended up being my favorite character at the end of this anime for her encouraging words she relayed to Ange. Dorothy learns it the hard way like the rest of the group does. Watch, find out for yourself if you enjoy Dorothy's presence or not. I sure did. 



Beatrice: I am not even going to bring up the ridiculous word we call loli. That would be cruel to her. I like how she's very loyal to the princess in the start and is weary of Ange especially. Can't blame her with Ange's way of expressing things. Difficult. When finding out she has a mechanical implant that affects her vocal cords, I could do nothing but shake my head. This is the only thing I will reveal that's strongly impacts her influence for this group of 5 wonderfully strong girls. She doesn't give in though. Please watch for yourself and enjoy. She too was great to behold. 


Princess Principal had a strong batch of characters. I feel a war could break out on who to love, like or trust more. 


Enjoyment: I am pleased to give this an 8. For a very underrated anime and one that I asked myself, would it be worth it? It surely was. I had a blast watching this. Spy work is the most dangerous road but an interesting one to learn and share. I loved the atmosphere in this show. Very intense. 


Overall: 8/10. Not an anime to overlook at all anymore. Still not well known yet. I really do hope whoever reads this tries this series for themselves.

A fun, original spy series with an interesting and well-realized setting. The overall aesthetic of the show is great with cool set pieces, appealing and highly original character designs, and excellent action choreography/animation. The soundtrack fits the show perfectly and adds to the immersion.
The story is interesting and has actually managed to surprise me a few times. Also, the way the early episodes are often not in chronological order is very effective in letting us know the information we need when we need it as viewers.
In terms of characters and characterization, I feel this is another of the show's strengths. Each character has a memorablepersonality and background, and all of them are fleshed out quite a lot for a 12-episode show.


Really, my only major complaint is that the show is only 12 episodes long. The middle of the season could easily have been drawn out into several full seasons worth of adventures, and I wouldn't have been bored.


Assuming the final episode doesn't disappoint me, this is a show that I will certainly be recommending to friends and hoping gets spin-offs and sequels.


**Edit now that the final episode has aired**


Fantastic. Just a great series. Leaves itself very open to sequels, and really needs one. I want to see what happens to this world and these characters. I hope this is a sign of great things to come.

Edit: I only want to add I hope for a sequel. It ends on a good note with personal relationships, but they truly left it open for further development among the characters. Especially with the lore in regards to the government, and their affairs. 
I wanted to wait until we had at least a few episodes to write a review, and after this week's episode, episode 6, then I can safely assure this is shaping up to be a great show. Granted, I will probably edit this review when the show ends since a good start could falter halfway through. Having said that, as ofnow this is a must-see show for most anime fans.


To start off the premise is a steampunk Victorian England. The art direction capturing this steampunk industrial revolution London is breathtaking at times. There are quite a few moments the direct does a wide angle shot when they are driving to show you the scale of the city, and it's amazingly beautiful as well. Obviously this being a work of fiction, then there are many sci-fi elements from the tools they use to how unique technology throughout the show. Meanwhile the character designs are great, and so are the action scenes. Overall the animation is top notch.


Meanwhile the basic premise of the story is we follow a series of spies in London where two major factions control the area. There is some political aspects here, but overall they aren't too confusing or convoluted. As of now only one's own personal motivations has been revealed, and each main character feels unique. In fact almost every character so far has had good character development, and after episode 6 we even have character specific episodes. As of now it truly feels like all of the main characters will get ample air time for their own development. 


Overall I don't want to go into more details since I feel like the premise and characters after a couple of episodes should suck many in. The only question is we are unsure if this is a 12 episode show, or a 24 episode show.

This will be my first anime review ever that I'm posting so I apologise in advance if I overstep any boundaries in this review.
As an appreciator of anime, having watched 100+ anime over the course of ~1.5 years (as of November 2018), I began to raise my expectations of anime that I consider to be enjoyable after experiencing the various overused anime gags and cliches. However, this superb anime proved to surpass all of my set expectations by a very wide margin. 
Story: 10/10
When I first saw this anime being telecasted on Animax, I was expecting a story plot resembling typical shounen anime filled withfanservice solely catered to the male audience (meaning boob-shots and beach episodes). Little did I know that I was in for a rollercoaster ride of emotions and deeply captivating story. We, the audience, are transported back to a fictional timeline set in the midst of the industrialization age of western Europe. In this fictional timeline, we are shown firsthand the conflicts between the various fictional world powers and socio classes in modern Europe through the perspectives of the diverse cast of characters consisting of royals, spies, nobles and even samurai. We get to see life in the upper classes and lower classes of modern Europe and the harshness of each livelihood accompanied with each lifestyle without any sugar coating. All I can say now without spoiling the story is that it's great and something you don't find in a lot of anime nowadays where the story isn't that complex and all-encompassing. Also, there's quite a bit of grit in the story which can serve to be a huge plus if you desire a rich story. Be prepared for a story filled with hardships and heart-wrenching emotions. Also, absolutely no fanservice.


Art: 7/10

The art style of this anime by itself does not warrant much praise as I find it to be just good. However, the real game-changer is not the art style but the setting of this anime where the characters are found in. Instead of the atypical modern setting most anime are found in, we are instead fed with gothic style architecture and classy style of clothing we often associate with the upper classes of society. The animation of this anime is also quite good; fighting scenes are considerably well executed. Although I didn't give the art such a high score, I thought that the art aspect of this anime was the most minor attribute when it came to grading this anime as I felt that there was a far stronger emphasis on the story and music, hence perhaps the lack of flair in the art style and thus found it easily overlooked when it comes to enjoying the anime. 


Sound: 10/10 

Words cannot express the degree of enjoyment I found in this anime's soundtrack. The music was fantastic in every regard in my opinion. Which goes to credit the one and only Yuki Kajura for her fantastic quality of work. The combination of jazz and string ensemble when it came to the provision of background music served only to reinforce the setting of an industrial age Europe which also complemented the fighting scenes of this anime. The OP of this anime provides you with an energetic feel before immersing you in the anime itself while the peaceful ED leaves you pondering over the intricacies of the story and leaves with you excellent music for you to ponder in deep thought. 


Character 9/10

Like the story, character development and the background is superbly executed and just plain enjoyable. We get to learn about the background of our main cast of characters and how it led to where they are. We learn to emphasize with them on a personal level. My only issue about this anime is that two of our characters don't get a lot of background story that they justly deserve. Because of that, I didn't get to appreciate these characters as much as I wished. In spite of this, the character development of the other characters helped to overshadow this small failure a great deal. 


Enjoyment: 10/10

Personally, I always put the story as the highest priority when it comes to enjoying an anime series. You can give me an anime with fantastic art and even soundtrack (I still consider soundtrack as a major factor when it comes to enjoying anime) but if the story is weak, then I'm sorry but all you're left with is a mediocre anime, above average at best. But with a fantastic story, soundtrack and cast of characters, you'll be left with an excellent anime in my opinion.


Overall: 10/10

Princess Principal is essentially a cute girls become friends and do stuff together anime, except the cute girls are all spies entwined in a war set in an incredibly dark steampunk setting. With amazing character designs, incredible directing, interesting construction, and use of use of both happy and incredibly dark tones this show has a lot to offer.
Ange, the main character of the show, has one of coolest anime costumes i've ever seen. She sports a black top hat with a slightly curved bill that exposes a crimson bottom. Matching the crimson and black pattern she wears a black cape that is crimson on theinside and wears black gloves that are crimson on the palm side of the hand. Under her cape she wears a black skin tight long sleeve top that looks like it's a turtle neck with some leather looking black stripes running up it, except the bottom part is a very short frilly tutu (also black). Lastly she has a brown leather strap fastened at her chest that wraps around her shoulders and black furry poofs wrapping around her neck and wrists.


The top hat, red undertones, and skin tight body suit, either intentionally or incidentally,  symbolize what this show has to offer excellently: the top hat reflects the steampunk setting, the red reflects the incredibly dark places this show goes, and the body suit reflects the functionality of a mobile spy outfit while at the same time showing off the body of one of many of this shows cute girls. Even the tutu could represent the happy slice of life interactions that happen in between the girls. 


The best part about this is that it isn't even Ange's only outfit and every character in the show has multiple amazing outfits that differ depending on the setting and it feels like an incredible amount of care was put into making the girls look great.


The direction of this show is particularly impressive because the show has conflicting tones of it being a dark spy drama while at the same time being a cute girls do things show and it manages to do this without either feel really breaking the other. All of the dark scenes that happen hit hard and fast and are never overplayed so when the show goes back to happier interactions between the girls it doesn't feel strange. This show manages to make great cute girls do laundry together scenes work in the same show where those same girls brutally murder people and it's amazing. Even with such a contrast in tone the action scenes where nicely choreographed, with Ange flying around with her gravity defying device, car chases, and Chise's sword play in particular with her fight in episode 5.


Princess Principal has an interesting structure in how it sort of feeds the viewer individual episodes that aren't always in the present that allows each of the primary characters backstories slowly be pieced together. The most gratifying part of the show for me was learning about each of the characters and how they came to their current situation and it helped that it was done non linearly because every jump back to the present after learning a backstory made the dynamic of the group feel different. The show doesn't really fully jump into a non episodical piece the story together mode into the last 2 episodes where it tries to put put together a finale, which ended up being my least favorite part of the show.


As for the music in the show the opening is fun and bombastic which really sets the mood for the show with a powerful female singer mirroring the powerful female characters in the show. The most rememberable ost from this show to me was Shadows and Fog, which is an atmospheric saxophone blasting combined voices chanting which manages combine the feel of spies and sabotage with the fun action of this show. Other than that there is a good track that has an SAO feel to it that plays during the episode 5 sword fight.


The only major negative feelings I have about the show are about it's story. The politics with the war and the command that order the girls around are not very interesting to me and it feels like they only exist to create an interesting setting. It's certainly not the worst executed story it's just that I don't feel particularly strongly about it whereas many other elements of the show I loved.


All in all Princess Principal is a really fun show that I would recommend watching if you are into stylish atmosphere, cute girls, incredibly dark moments, interesting characters, and fun action.


8/10

This is my first review but I really wanted to make this show my first one. I started watching this anime because I wanted a small break from studying since it looked interesting. And damn, has it been a ride. 
I will now just go through the different points I've given and explain why I did so.
Story: 10/10
The story in Princess Principal is not chronological as it jumps back in time several times to explain how the different characters met and learned how to work together. This can be confusing at times but the series does somewhat help you by giving you the "Case numbers"at the start of each episode. 

While the episodes (cases) don't necessarily look connected, the anime does have an overarching plotline. This anime is definitely not a Moe SOL like K-on! Like what the artstyle might make you believe. 


Art: 10/10

I'm a very big fan of the artstyle. I like the setting, steampunk London, and the generally dark backgrounds. The anime does a great job contrasting the rich parts of London with the poor industrial parts with it's colour schemes. The animation in the action scenes is just great and incredibly fluent. The artists really did a magnificent job. The character design is very nice too, the style does resemble K-on, Sora No Woto and other "cute girl" anime a lot (which in my opinion isn't a bad thing at all) 


Sound: 10/10

I'm not a big specialist on the sound department but everything I've heard didn't bother me and the soundtrack is amazing, I'm especially a big fan of the intro, the ending is a complete different style but definitely not bad either.


Character: 10/10

The character backstories are amazing, every girl has her own unique reasons why they are banding together and why they became spies. The character backstories of the characters play a big role in the overarching plotline of the anime, it's just incredibly well-integrated. My personal favourite is "Dorothy", the oldest of the spies, her nature and even her chosen name get explained in her own backstory episode,  which each character has. There's nothing much for me to say about this except that I'm speechless about how well they covered this part, totally unexpected. The anime I've seen generally don't do this. 


Enjoyment: 10/10

I've been sucked into the story completely, from the first episode I was entirely sold. There's not one single moment at which I felt bored or uninterested, I was almost on the edge of my seat the entire time.


Overall: 10/10

I know this isn't a nuanced opinion at all, but I really enjoy watching this show so much that I can't find anything bad to say about it. I've been recommending this anime to my friends almost non-stop and I will do the same here. If you like spy-shows, steampunk, intrigue, good character development, original anime, or just a show you can sit down for and relax, please do check out this anime. I'm sure you won't regret it!

Princess Principal ended up being a surprisingly pleasant watch. It was definitely more of a serious story than I was expecting. The tone that one can expect was established straight from the onset. The way how the story was structured, the unresolved plot points clearly indicate that there the is a second season planned. However, the way how the story feels all over the place may be upsetting to some. 
The art was good and the moe art style didn't detract much from the tone of the anime. The animation when it came down to the action in the show, whether it was the carchases, the fights or anything else was excellent. The soundtrack was stellar and it's one of those that is memorable and sticks out every time you hear one of the tracks. The characters were great and while we got insight to many of the main cast, I still feel there is room for them to get more development than they have received so far.\n
The story for Princess Principal ended nicely enough but it would be great if we can get a continuation someday to fully flesh out the story.

And the award for misleading title of the year goes to....... Princess Principal!!!!!  
Princess Principal is a dark and fluffy semi steam-punk adventure that bounces around but never makes an impact. The animations is nice, the characters are interesting, fun, mesh well and have very interesting backstories. The plot is absent of many cliches, which is a good thing and the concept leaves you wanting more but the 12 episode format almost certainly killed this shows potential. I watched this show as a Sub and enjoyed the voice actors performance, but I will say a british english dub would definitely take this show toanother level. The only thing that I cant get past is the short non linear plot that seems to jump around all over the place, and As soon as you get pulled in its over.  Its not a waste of time though, think of it as  an anime appetizer.

Story: Overall I thought they would make more use of the steampunk vibe and culture they were living in, but at times it was just a regular crime/spy anime. I thought the first episode was really well done. While i wasn't a fan of the different cases at times, they did a good job delivering the story to the viewers.
Art and Animation: Sloppy at times but really well done. The fight scenes were amazing especially the Sword fights with Chise.
Sound and Voice: The opening and ending were two of the best of the Summer 2017 season in my opinion. Add in an awesome BGM andI barely had any problems. The VA's were great. Not masterful but great. If anything Ange's VA did a spectacular job going back and from from a serious voice to a more girlish voice.


Characters: Really awesome cast of females and real original. Ange is such an awesome character. Obviously my favorite especially with her being from the Black Lizard Planet, I loved that about her. Dorothy was great, Beatrice was annoying at points but she had her moments. Chise was freaking awesome. And the Princess was the Princess not the best character but a necessity.


Enjoyment: There were times where I would miss an episode, watch it about a week later and say "Damn how could I miss this episode?!?!" That proved to me how much I enjoyed this anime and caught it every day it came out. Really good and underrated anime.


Overall: I know this anime is not for most people. People who enjoy a more serious Spy anime won't enjoy it but I think this is the best Spy anime made so far. Yes better then Joker Game. I feel with the Inception and actually doing infiltration by disguise was a step up from Joker Game. Plus after episode one I was blown away by how serious this anime could get at times.


Definitely and underrated anime, and I think that blame falls on the company who licensed Princess Principal for not pushing it as much as they should have.

Espionage has always been an intriguing look into people who essentially needs to hide everything about themselves and still get information out of people. Some do this in boring fashion like Joker Game, Princess Principal on the other hand does this in spades AND makes it interesting!.
The first thing LA would like to address is that the cute girls doing things, well in Princess Principal's case is that at first looks like this but very quickly you will realize that Princess Principal is more focused on it's clandestine missions that links to prior missions and dialogue that's clever and always keeps you on your toesis all the more important in this anime.


Princess Principal may look like the daily lives of spies in a steampunk alternative 19th century London, however it has deeper meaning when it comes to our two main characters of this anime Ange voiced by Ayaka Imamura and Princess voiced by Akira Sekine. The rest of the Princess Spy Team consisting of Dorothy voiced by You Taichi the leader, Chise voiced by Nozomi Furuki an exchange student from Japan and a literal ninja spy tasked in observing the main cast and Beatrice voiced by Akari Kageyama, the Princess' aide and close friend. Dorothy gets a bit of character development during one of the missions that involves her father and it's "tragic" to say the least but nonetheless she becomes a better character from it and what kind of upbringing she came from. Her character development also helps Beatrice as at first she was a really clingy character to Princess and was very pushy but her opening up to Dorothy as well as having similar upbringings did help her case. Chise on the other hand gets the most development outside of Ange and Princess, from her getting used to London to her own personal mission the first time we see her brought alot out of her. Ange is LA's favourite character without a doubt, from her badassness in how she deals with missions to her entire backstory with the Princess that however leads into spoilers, but you see her plight either way. Nonetheless Ange was probably the best thing about this anime and is truly a great counterintelligence spy and a great liar no matter what way you look at her.


Princess Principal's plot format has an anachronic order of missions that presents itself, such as the very first episode being case 13, not 1 and etc etc. This does help shake up things in the long run as it gives us context to certain missions that occurred before or after certain other missions meaning that by majority the missions are linked in certain situations of the anime through cameos or certain characters showing up who were villains previously or afterwards. Yes Princess Principal did the entire Haruhi Suzumiya route for anachronic storytelling but you know what?, they still did it to great effect. The only problem LA saw from this was that Princess Principal case goes up to 24 yet there is only 12 episodes in total for this anime. What LA wanted to see was ALL 24 episodes shown but LA could say that even managing this anime to go on for 24 episodes would have been difficult from a storytelling stand point but LA would wanted to see all 24 cases nonetheless.


The animation done by Actas and Studio 3Hz was amazing right down to the aesthetics of the anime's atmosphere of a steampunk 19th century alternative London espionage anime. It's gritty yet elegantly steampunk all at the same time and Actas and Studio 3Hz has done amazing with this. The fights scenes were fluid and amazingly bombastic at times and even the standoffs the Princess team faces off with gets gripping. The character designs are amazing if anything having the sense and aesthetics of where they are as well, with props going to Chise and Ange, though the entire cast goes through this.


The voice acting, well there are two voice actors LA really needs to talk about Ayaka Imamura and Akira Sekine as Ange and Princess respectively, Ayaka Imamura for showing off her various differing vocal ranges from moe, to deadpan to delinquent and even more from that. Akira Sekine also gets it merely due to the dramatic turn her character goes through and Akira's acting chops were up to snuff for it and LA commends this. The rest of the voice cast from You Taichi and Nozomi Furuki were great additions as well though Beatrice's Akari Kageyama got a bit of time to get used to, her being a semi-squeaker at the start of the anime and all and Beatrice's personality not helping her character's case.


Princess Principal's finale however is one LA was skeptical about to say the least, as it felt slightly rushed and everything that occurred in the finale was "washed away" rather quickly. Because of this, LA did think Princess Principal had to be 24 episodes long so that all the pieces could have been done better and given us a more bombastic climax than what we have gotten. LA was expecting more from this ending is the best way to say it and as much the final arc is projected itself rather easily, LA was just expecting more really. On speaking of flaws, as much as it's anachronic order was a great idea to Princess Principal, LA also wanted to rest of the cases that were missing in the anachronic order to be shown to us, you know, like the audience able to find all the pieces to see them fit, instead we have a jigsaw puzzle that's half complete. LA thinks the only flaw LA WILL defend about Princess Principal is their backstory, as yeah they are spies, thus they really shouldn't have much backstory about them and even then Princess Principal manages to subtly give backstory and character development to the Princess Team through the missions they go through and heck even the member's mannerism and behavior towards each other reflect many of the characters in question as well, Ange being an exception at times because we could never get a hold of what's she's thinking right now which is ALSO a plus to the plot progression of Princess Principal.


Princess Principal is by all means for LA, a great espionage anime, sure it has cute girls doing spy things but it's cute girls doing spy things done right especially when it concerns spying and the like.
